text: North Korea said on Sunday that it had locked down a city near its border with South Korea and declared a “maximum” national emergency after finding what its leader, Kim Jong-un, said could be the country’s first case of Covid-19 there. https://t.co/NVVkydPPcP

name: nytimes
text:
RT @SarahMaslinNir: Are your trousers a ‘lil tighter after lockdown? You’re not alone. In NYC letting out pants is big (lol) business right now.  According to the city’s tailors: “Everybody got fat!”

text: A small plane with 6 aboard crashed into a backyard in a residential section of a city in Utah on Saturday afternoon, sending a fireball hundreds of feet into the air, an official said. https://t.co/Hhz1jYjlE2

name: nytimes
text: Wasps get a bad rap. And sometimes, they deserve it. But they’re not all “murder hornets.” Here’s how to appreciate — and not tick off — these creatures we share summer with. https://t.co/QyJYgfQQYD

name: nytimes
text: About 150 demonstrators showed up on Saturday to a protest in Illinois billed as the “Million Unmasked March." Even as the virus continues to surge, pockets of resistance to public health measures continue to appear in parts of the U.S. https://t.co/NruiihJsw7

text: "I am desperate to smell the earth and air in a naturally farmed vineyard, to walk in a forest or stumble barefoot through a stream." https://t.co/rBzCxAVKD5

name: nytimes
text:
Demonstrators marched in Seattle and Los Angeles on Saturday, clashing with police as they protested the aggressive actions of federal agents in Portland, Oregon. At a rally in Aurora, Colorado, a car drove into a crowd walking along a highway.

text:
Across the country, protests widened in solidarity with the marchers in Portland, Oregon. In Seattle, demonstrators smashed windows and set fires, and 21 police officers were injured. A shooting at a protest in Austin, Texas, left one man dead.

https://t.co/Yu8e5ny49F

name: nytimes
text: The pandemic has brought kids a special kind of freedom: the ability to play like nobody’s watching. Because, much of the time, nobody is. Here’s how risky play helps children explore and conquer fears. https://t.co/iMlMwLwE5c

name: nytimes
text: RT @caitlinroper: In your @nytimes this Sunday 7/26, the July issue of The New York Times for Kids! https://t.co/avySiCHDmB

name: nytimes
text:
Today is the 30th anniversary of the passage of the Americans With Disabilities Act, a landmark law secured after years of activism.

Our series explores the history of the disability rights movement and what it means to live with a disability in America. https://t.co/vdTwweBHfv

name: nytimes
text: The modern disability civil rights movement encapsulates many distinct experiences, but the prevailing themes are of community, justice and equity. Here are a few of the moments that have stood out in the collective memories of disability advocates. https://t.co/RPamn1xBsy

name: nytimes
text: Millions of young people grew up knowing the Americans With Disabilities Act as a birthright. With an expanded view of disability justice that embraces other causes and marginalized groups, they are pushing for the act to live up to its promises. https://t.co/88IWJnYB0o

name: nytimes
text: We asked the disability rights activists Judy Heumann, Alice Wong and Haben Girma to reflect on the 30th anniversary of the Americans With Disabilities Act. They said the work of a civil rights activist is never done. https://t.co/rLBlu4UTox https://t.co/UpKJU81o8Y

name: nytimes
text:
“Legislation is ‘one size fits all’ — invisible disabilities are not.”

While accommodating people with invisible disabilities is mandated by law, what specifically constitutes a disability is opaque, and what constitutes accommodation is just as vague. https://t.co/xdsjScmuQq

name: nytimes
text: “It wasn’t until I started trying to meet men online that I suddenly had to confront my cerebral palsy every time I had a conversation,” Ryan J. Haddad writes. He is one of 3 writers who shared stories of revealing their disability to others. https://t.co/GMbCVYtW55 https://t.co/ObOLQsFNw0

name: nytimes
text: While highly theoretical when it comes to eliminating disabilities, gene editing has drawn the attention of the disability community. The prospect of erasing some perceived deficiencies hovers at the margins of what people consider ethically acceptable. https://t.co/qm7XapIq3o

name: nytimes
text: Hiring underrepresented workers should not be viewed as heroic, disability advocates say. Disabled workers should not be treated as inspirations for merely working a 9-to-5 job like nondisabled people do every day. https://t.co/X69FeiefwR

name: nytimes
text:
Representation matters, yet actors with disabilities are rarely tapped to play disabled characters. Ali Stroker, Marlee Matlin and others share their views on representation in the entertainment industry. https://t.co/QANBPqAxDa 
https://t.co/UKswgLkU2G

name: nytimes
text: “The industry has always had trouble supporting and promoting musicians with disabilities, especially Black musicians,” writes Leroy F. Moore Jr., one of the founding members of Krip-Hop Nation https://t.co/aPakLTCgWl https://t.co/wqB17jl53N

name: nytimes
text: Designers in the disability community are drawn to innovations that embed accessibility into everyday technologies and the spaces that we all share. Also, they want people to stop trying to solve problems that don’t exist. https://t.co/H3GJfbrwBb https://t.co/uS3PKGwit9

name: nytimes
text: “As a disabled person, I long for the independence and the ability to choose how I express myself; the fashion industry should be a place where that is made possible,” Keah Brown writes. https://t.co/Ygy8qSKyqk
